Text.content:
The most important aspect of a CMS website template is, of course, that editors can add new contents to a web page. An area on a page where content editors can drag and drop contents onto, is called a Container. A container is like a parking place for contents. Even if empty, a container takes up a certain amount of space. The space can be occupied by one ore more elements of different types. There are rules that cause not every element type may occupy a certain container. And there is a maximum limit of available content element slots.

In the example below, the <cms:container> is named main. A template JSP may contain more than one container. The individual name should be unique for the template JSP itself and all outsourced JSP files included by means of the <cms:include> tag. 

The container in the example is of type element, which means that any formatter also defining the container type named element may occupy this container. The container type name element is freely choosen but must match any formatter's container type to be useful.

The maxElements attribute restricts the size of the container to a maximum number of 30 elements.

Inside the container, there is a HTML <div> representing the drop area, where editors can drag and drop new contents. Make sure that this <div> has a defined width and height, event if empty.

In larger website projects where different user groups are responsible for the edition of specific logical parts of a website (header, footer, layout, contents), it might be useful to use the editableby attribute.
